elements.content: The self-assembly of LiBr and bis(diphenylphosphineoxo)ethane (dppe-O) in tetrahydrofuran (THF) and further diffusion with n-pentane gave rise to a new coordination polymer formulated as [Li2(dppe-O)3Br2] n and has been shown by X-ray diffraction analysis to be a 2-D noninterpenetrating honeycomb-like layer of (6,3) topology containing 42-membered rings with 1-D hydrophobic channels. These 2-D layers stack together tightly through weak hydrogen bonding and strong π···π stacking interactions to form a 3-D nanoporous structure.
elements.clean_text: The self-assembly of LiBr and bis(diphenylphosphineoxo)ethane (dppe-O) in tetrahydrofuran (THF) and further diffusion with n-pentane gave rise to a new coordination polymer formulated as [Li2(dppe-O)3Br2] n  and has been shown by X-ray diffraction analysis to be a 2-D noninterpenetrating honeycomb-like layer of (6,3) topology containing 42-membered rings with 1-D hydrophobic channels. These 2-D layers stack together tightly through weak hydrogen bonding and strong π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions to form a 3-D nanoporous structure.

elements.content: A novel 2-D noninterpenetrating honeycomb-like lithium coordination polymer [Li2(dppe-O)3Br2] n has been synthesized in absolute THF solution, which exhibits an open framework of (6,3) topology containing 42-membered rings with 1-D hydrophobic channels.
elements.clean_text: A novel 2-D noninterpenetrating honeycomb-like lithium coordination polymer [Li2(dppe-O)3Br2] n  has been synthesized in absolute THF solution, which exhibits an open framework of (6,3) topology containing 42-membered rings with 1-D hydrophobic channels.

elements.content: Self-assembly of microporous metal−organic frameworks with specific topologies has attracted a great deal of interest in recent years due to their potential properties as functional solid materials as well as fascinating molecular structures. In particular, these frameworks assembled with metal centers and organic molecules may yield channels or cavities of various sizes and shapes. However, these microporous frameworks commonly fail to realize their full potential for porosity because of interpenetration or self-inclusion of identical framework if the void is more than 50% of the crystal by volume. One approach to the preparation of robust frameworks has been to employ rigid linkers such as 4,4‘-bipyridine and 1,3,5-benzentricarboxylate, which offer important advantages due to their rigidity and consequent tendency to form rigid secondary building units (SBUs) in the extended solids. While far less common has been the use of flexible bridging linkers in the construction of extended robust frameworks, this approach is becoming attractive recently because the flexibility and conformational freedom of such ligands offer the possibility of generating unique frameworks with useful properties.
elements.clean_text: Self-assembly of microporous metal-organic frameworks with specific topologies has attracted a great deal of interest in recent years due to their potential properties as functional solid materials as well as fascinating molecular structures. In particular, these frameworks assembled with metal centers and organic molecules may yield channels or cavities of various sizes and shapes. However, these microporous frameworks commonly fail to realize their full potential for porosity because of interpenetration or self-inclusion of identical framework if the void is more than 50% of the crystal by volume. One approach to the preparation of robust frameworks has been to employ rigid linkers such as 4,4‘-bipyridine and 1,3,5-benzentricarboxylate, which offer important advantages due to their rigidity and consequent tendency to form rigid secondary building units (SBUs) in the extended solids. While far less common has been the use of flexible bridging linkers in the construction of extended robust frameworks, this approach is becoming attractive recently because the flexibility and conformational freedom of such ligands offer the possibility of generating unique frameworks with useful properties.

elements.content: In this context, we chose the long bridging bis(diphenylphosphineoxo)ethane (dppe-O) ligand as a flexible linker, similar to the 1,4-bis(phenyl-sulfinyl)ethane and its analogues, which are good ligands to form multidimensional coordination polymers with various topologies. On the other hand, open frameworks construction through organic ligands with both transition metals and rare earth elements in which the metal ions act as nodes to form macrometallocyles have been widely investigated, while with alkali or alkaline earth metal ions remain scant in the literature. In present communication, LiBr and dppe-O were selected as nodes and linkers in the self-assembly reaction, respectively, and resulted in to our best knowledge the first example of a 2-D coordination polymer based on bridging bisphosphineoxo ligands, namely, [Li2(dppe-O)3Br2] n (1), which exhibits a 2-D noninterpenetrating honeycomb-like open framework of (6,3) topology containing 42-membered rings with 1-D hydrophobic channels. It should be noted that noninterpenerating neutral frameworks with large macrometallocyles remain scant according to the literature.
elements.clean_text: In this context, we chose the long bridging bis(diphenylphosphineoxo)ethane (dppe-O) ligand as a flexible linker, similar to the 1,4-bis(phenyl-sulfinyl)ethane and its analogues, which are good ligands to form multidimensional coordination polymers with various topologies. On the other hand, open frameworks construction through organic ligands with both transition metals and rare earth elements in which the metal ions act as nodes to form macrometallocyles have been widely investigated, while with alkali or alkaline earth metal ions remain scant in the literature. In present communication, LiBr and dppe-O were selected as nodes and linkers in the self-assembly reaction, respectively, and resulted in to our best knowledge the first example of a 2-D coordination polymer based on bridging bisphosphineoxo ligands, namely, [Li2(dppe-O)3Br2] n  (1), which exhibits a 2-D noninterpenetrating honeycomb-like open framework of (6,3) topology containing 42-membered rings with 1-D hydrophobic channels. It should be noted that noninterpenerating neutral frameworks with large macrometallocyles remain scant according to the literature.

elements.content: The reaction of LiBr and dppe-O in THF under N2 atmosphere and further diffusion with n-pentane gave rise to light yellow crystals of 1. The element analysis and IR spectrum confirm the formula of 1. X-ray single-crystal diffraction reveals complex 1 has a 2-D honeycomb-like open framework of (6,3) topology constructed from lithium ions and dppe-O ligands functioning as bridging linkers through their oxygen atoms. As shown in Figure , one crystallographically independent lithium atom in the center of slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry is coordinated by a bromine atom and three oxygen atoms from three dppe-O ligands. The lithium atom and bromine atom lie on a 3-fold axis, and therefore LiBr may act as a perfect tripod-shaped vertex, a good candidate for a corrugated (6,3) sheet. The Li−Br and Li−O bond distances are 2.547(4) and 1.924(2) Å, respectively, which are in good agreement with those found in the relevant literature. The dppe-O ligand with an inversion center bridges two lithium atoms through its two oxygen atoms in trans positions with a P(1)−O(1)−Li(1) bond angle of 158.9(1)° and a C(13C)−C(13)−P(1) (symmetry code:  C:  1 − x, 1 − y, −z) bond angle of 112.5(1)°. Six dppe-O linkers alternately bridge six LiBr moieties to form a corrugated hexagonal 42-membered ring, in which three nonadjacent lithium atoms are coplanar paralleling that of the remaining three nonadjacent lithium atoms with a plane-to-plane distance of 2.930 Å. The hexagonal rings are edge-sharing to each other to yield a 2-D honeycomb-like framework along the a−b directions (Figure ), which can be regarded as a (6,3) topology net with lithium atoms acting as “3-connected” centers and Li(ddpe-O)3/2Br units being regarded as repeating units.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of LiBr and dppe-O in THF under N2 atmosphere and further diffusion with n-pentane gave rise to light yellow crystals of 1. The element analysis and IR spectrum confirm the formula of 1. X-ray single-crystal diffraction reveals complex 1 has a 2-D honeycomb-like open framework of (6,3) topology constructed from lithium ions and dppe-O ligands functioning as bridging linkers through their oxygen atoms. As shown in Figure , one crystallographically independent lithium atom in the center of slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry is coordinated by a bromine atom and three oxygen atoms from three dppe-O ligands. The lithium atom and bromine atom lie on a 3-fold axis, and therefore LiBr may act as a perfect tripod-shaped vertex, a good candidate for a corrugated (6,3) sheet. The Li-Br and Li-O bond distances are 2.547(4) and 1.924(2) Å, respectively, which are in good agreement with those found in the relevant literature. The dppe-O ligand with an inversion center bridges two lithium atoms through its two oxygen atoms in trans positions with a P(1)-O(1)-Li(1) bond angle of 158.9(1)° and a C(13C)-C(13)-P(1) (symmetry code: C: 1 - x, 1 - y, -z) bond angle of 112.5(1)°. Six dppe-O linkers alternately bridge six LiBr moieties to form a corrugated hexagonal 42-membered ring, in which three nonadjacent lithium atoms are coplanar paralleling that of the remaining three nonadjacent lithium atoms with a plane-to-plane distance of 2.930 Å. The hexagonal rings are edge-sharing to each other to yield a 2-D honeycomb-like framework along the a-b directions (Figure ), which can be regarded as a (6,3) topology net with lithium atoms acting as "3-connected" centers and Li(ddpe-O)3/2Br units being regarded as repeating units.

elements.content: The coordination environments of lithium atoms in1 with 30% thermal ellipsoids. Selected bond distances (Å) and angles (°):  Li(1)−O(1), 1.924(2); Li(1)−O(1A), 1.924(2); Li(1)−O(1B), 1.924(2); Li(1)−Br(1), 2.547(4); P(1)−O(1), 1.482(1); P(1)−C(13), 1.799(2); C(13)−C(13C), 1.523(3); P(1)−C(1), 1.803(1); P(1)−C(7), 1.800(2); O(1)−Li(1)−Br(1), 107.7(1); O(1A)−Li(1)−Br(1), 107.7(1); O(1B)−Li(1)−Br(1), 107.7(1); O(1A)−Li(1)−O(1), 111.2(1); O(1B)−Li(1)−O(1), 111.2(1); O(1)−P(1)−C(13), 114.30(7); O(1)−P(1)−C(7), 110.63(7); P(1)−O(1)−Li(1), 158.9(1); C(13C)−C(13)−P(1), 112.5(1). Symmetry codes A:  1 − x + y, 1 − x, z; B:  1 − y, x − y, −z; C:  1 − x, 1 − y, −z.

2-D noninterpenetrating honeycomb-like layers of (6,3) topology with 1-D channels along thec axis. The yellow insets show the 1-D perforative bulblike channels with minimum cavities represented as cyan spheres.
elements.clean_text: 2  2-D noninterpenetrating honeycomb-like layers of (6,3) topology with 1-D channels along thec axis. The yellow insets show the 1-D perforative bulblike channels with minimum cavities represented as cyan spheres.

elements.content: In the layers, there are abundant C−H···Br hydrogen bonding interactions, which play an important role in stabilizing the (6,3) topology net (Figure , Table S1, Supporting Information). One-half phenyl rings of dppe-O ligands stretch toward the centers of the hexagonal 42-membered rings with their aromatic ring planes approximately parallel to the a−b plane, while the remaining half phenyl rings of dppe-O ligands stretch out of the a−b plane, which are parallel to each other between the adjacent layers with a phenyl ring centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.861 Å and a plane-to-plane distance of 3.571 Å, indicating that there exist strong π···π stacking interactions. Both the weak hydrogen bonding interactions and the strong π···π stacking interactions induce to form a 3-D noninterpenetrating nanoporous framework with 1-D hydrophobic and perforative bulblike channels with the effective minimum and maximum diameters of 2.67 and 6.84 Å when the layers stack together along the c axis (Figure ), suggesting that compound 1 may be suitable for storing hydrogen since the minimum diameter of the channel is larger than that of hydrogen. It should be noted that the solvent-accessible volume in the present coordination polymer is approximate 204.5 Å3 per unit cell volume, and the pore volume ratio is calculated to be 10.6% using the PLATON program.
elements.clean_text: In the layers, there are abundant C-H⋅⋅⋅Br hydrogen bonding interactions, which play an important role in stabilizing the (6,3) topology net (Figure , Table S1, Supporting Information). One-half phenyl rings of dppe-O ligands stretch toward the centers of the hexagonal 42-membered rings with their aromatic ring planes approximately parallel to the a-b plane, while the remaining half phenyl rings of dppe-O ligands stretch out of the a-b plane, which are parallel to each other between the adjacent layers with a phenyl ring centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.861 Å and a plane-to-plane distance of 3.571 Å, indicating that there exist strong π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions. Both the weak hydrogen bonding interactions and the strong π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions induce to form a 3-D noninterpenetrating nanoporous framework with 1-D hydrophobic and perforative bulblike channels with the effective minimum and maximum diameters of 2.67 and 6.84 Å when the layers stack together along the c axis (Figure ), suggesting that compound 1 may be suitable  for storing hydrogen since the minimum diameter of the channel is larger than that of hydrogen. It should be noted that the solvent-accessible volume in the present coordination polymer is approximate 204.5 Å3 per unit cell volume, and the pore volume ratio is calculated to be 10.6% using the PLATON program.

elements.content: 3-D packing diagram for1 reveals intramolecular C−H···Br hydrogen bonds represented as red dash lines and π···π stacking interactions between adjacent phenyl rings of adjacent layers represented as black dash lines.
elements.clean_text: 3  3-D packing diagram for1 reveals intramolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅Br hydrogen bonds represented as red dash lines and π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions between adjacent phenyl rings of adjacent layers represented as black dash lines.

elements.content: The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) study shows that the weight loss of 90.05% (calcd:  88.14%) observed from 30 to 500 °C with a decomposition point T onset of 325.9 °C corresponds to the loss of three dppe-O ligands per formula unit (Figure S1, Supporting Information), which reveals the good stability of the present microporous framework due to the abundant supermolecular interactions between and within the layers. The solid-state luminescence spectrum of 1 at ambient temperature exhibits an intense narrow band fluorescent emission at 692 nm on photoexcitation at 361 nm (Figure S2, Supporting Information), suggesting that compound 1 may be suitable as a candidate for a stable red fluorescent material due to its stability in air.
elements.clean_text: The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) study shows that the weight loss of 90.05% (calcd: 88.14%) observed from 30 to 500 °C with a decomposition point T onset of 325.9 °C corresponds to the loss of three dppe-O ligands per formula unit (Figure S1, Supporting Information), which reveals the good stability of the present microporous framework due to the abundant supermolecular interactions between and within the layers. The solid-state luminescence spectrum of 1 at ambient temperature exhibits an intense narrow band fluorescent emission at 692 nm on photoexcitation at 361 nm (Figure S2, Supporting Information), suggesting that compound 1 may be suitable as a candidate for a stable red fluorescent material due to its stability in air.

elements.content: The TGA spectrum, solid-state electronic emission spectrum, IR spectrum, geometrical characteristics of the C−H···Br hydrogen bonds table for 1 and X-ray crystallographic information (CIF) file for the crystal of 1. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text:
Supporting Information Available 

The TGA spectrum, solid-state electronic emission spectrum, IR spectrum, geometrical characteristics of the C-H⋅⋅⋅Br hydrogen bonds table for 1 and X-ray crystallographic information (CIF) file for the crystal of 1. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
In the layers, there are abundant C−H···Br hydrogen bonding interactions, which play an important role in stabilizing the (6,3) topology net (Figure , Table S1, Supporting Information). One-half phenyl rings of dppe-O ligands stretch toward the centers of the hexagonal 42-membered rings with their aromatic ring planes approximately parallel to the a−b plane, while the remaining half phenyl rings of dppe-O ligands stretch out of the a−b plane, which are parallel to each other between the adjacent layers with a phenyl ring centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.861 Å and a plane-to-plane distance of 3.571 Å, indicating that there exist strong π···π stacking interactions. Both the weak hydrogen bonding interactions and the strong π···π stacking interactions induce to form a 3-D noninterpenetrating nanoporous framework with 1-D hydrophobic and perforative bulblike channels with the effective minimum and maximum diameters of 2.67 and 6.84 Å when the layers stack together along the c axis (Figure ), suggesting that compound 1 may be suitable for storing hydrogen since the minimum diameter of the channel is larger than that of hydrogen. It should be noted that the solvent-accessible volume in the present coordination polymer is approximate 204.5 Å3 per unit cell volume, and the pore volume ratio is calculated to be 10.6% using the PLATON program.

The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) study shows that the weight loss of 90.05% (calcd:  88.14%) observed from 30 to 500 °C with a decomposition point T onset of 325.9 °C corresponds to the loss of three dppe-O ligands per formula unit (Figure S1, Supporting Information), which reveals the good stability of the present microporous framework due to the abundant supermolecular interactions between and within the layers. The solid-state luminescence spectrum of 1 at ambient temperature exhibits an intense narrow band fluorescent emission at 692 nm on photoexcitation at 361 nm (Figure S2, Supporting Information), suggesting that compound 1 may be suitable as a candidate for a stable red fluorescent material due to its stability in air.
cln_elements.clean_text:
In the layers, there are abundant C-H⋅⋅⋅Br hydrogen bonding interactions, which play an important role in stabilizing the (6,3) topology net (Figure , Table S1, Supporting Information). One-half phenyl rings of dppe-O ligands stretch toward the centers of the hexagonal 42-membered rings with their aromatic ring planes approximately parallel to the a-b plane, while the remaining half phenyl rings of dppe-O ligands stretch out of the a-b plane, which are parallel to each other between the adjacent layers with a phenyl ring centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.861 Å and a plane-to-plane distance of 3.571 Å, indicating that there exist strong π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions. Both the weak hydrogen bonding interactions and the strong π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions induce to form a 3-D noninterpenetrating nanoporous framework with 1-D hydrophobic and perforative bulblike channels with the effective minimum and maximum diameters of 2.67 and 6.84 Å when the layers stack together along the c axis (Figure ), suggesting that compound 1 may be suitable  for storing hydrogen since the minimum diameter of the channel is larger than that of hydrogen. It should be noted that the solvent-accessible volume in the present coordination polymer is approximate 204.5 Å3 per unit cell volume, and the pore volume ratio is calculated to be 10.6% using the PLATON program.  

The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) study shows that the weight loss of 90.05% (calcd: 88.14%) observed from 30 to 500 °C with a decomposition point T onset of 325.9 °C corresponds to the loss of three dppe-O ligands per formula unit (Figure S1, Supporting Information), which reveals the good stability of the present microporous framework due to the abundant supermolecular interactions between and within the layers. The solid-state luminescence spectrum of 1 at ambient temperature exhibits an intense narrow band fluorescent emission at 692 nm on photoexcitation at 361 nm (Figure S2, Supporting Information), suggesting that compound 1 may be suitable as a candidate for a stable red fluorescent material due to its stability in air.

decomposition temperature.condition: weight loss of 90.05% observed from 30 to 500 °C

metadata.title:
A Novel 2-D Honeycomb-like Lithium Coordination Polymer
Containing 42-Membered Rings
